page.title: 07REVIEWING NEWHAVEN'S PAST
page.content: Castle Hill had Neolithic, Celtic and Roman settlements. Under the Police Station is a Roman villa. Newhaven's Saxon name was Meeching. A Saxon cemetery was found at Bishopstone and Saxon, Norman and Meeching roads recall the past. The settlement was renamed Newhaven in the 16th century when the course of the river was rechannelled to exit at its present mouth because Seaford port, its original outlet, became silted up. The ferry has been replaced in turn by a tilt bridge, swing bridge and an electically controlled bridge. A Dieppe Ferry service made Newhaven an important South Coast port. Tidemills once had a flour mill using tidal power. A workhouse was built in 1836 for the poor and a fort as protection from French attack, 1868. In 1942 the ill fated Dieppe Raid left from here.
